message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactase deficiency, as it can cause nonbloody diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. Stool sampling revealing decreased stool pH also supports this diagnosis. Options A and B are related to autoimmune diseases, and option C is related to E. coli infection, which usually resolves within a few days.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased stool pH suggests malabsorption of carbohydrates, which can be caused by lactase deficiency. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells are involved in inflammation but there is no evidence of inflammation from the symptoms described. Anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, which would not cause a decrease in stool pH. Heat-labile toxin is associated with E. coli infection, but the coworkers' symptoms lasted only 3 days, while the patient's symptoms have persisted for 2 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged symptoms and decreased stool pH suggest lactase deficiency which can cause nonbloody diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. Options A and B are not related to the symptoms and Option C suggests an acute diarrheal illness which typically resolves within a few days.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged symptoms, nonbloody diarrhea, and decreased stool pH suggest lactase deficiency, which can result from an acute gastroenteritis illness. The other options do not match the symptoms presented by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of lactose intolerance, which can cause diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. The decreased stool pH is consistent with lactose intolerance as well. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells and anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, while heat-labile toxin is associated with E. coli infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lactase deficiency, which can cause nonbloody diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. Stool sampling revealing decreased stool pH is consistent with this diagnosis. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells and anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, whereas heat-labile toxin is associated with enterotoxigenic E. coli infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of lactose intolerance. Decreased stool pH is also one of the indicators of lactase deficiency. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells and anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, and heat-labile toxin is associated with E. coli infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactase deficiency, which can cause nonbloody diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. Decreased stool pH can also be a sign of lactase deficiency. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells are involved in inflammatory bowel disease, anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, and heat-labile toxin is associated with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli, but none of these conditions match the patient's symptoms and stool findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased stool pH indicates a lactase deficiency, which can lead to prolonged symptoms of diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells are associated with inflammatory bowel disease, while anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease. Heat-labile toxin is associated with some strains of E. coli infection, but the symptoms are usually self-limited and do not persist for 2 weeks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decreased stool pH suggests lactase deficiency, which can cause prolonged symptoms of diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and bloating after consuming dairy products. Intestinal type 1 helper T cells are involved in autoimmune diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease, but there is no indication of an autoimmune disease in this case. Anti-endomysial antibodies are associated with celiac disease, which can cause diarrhea but would not explain the coworkers' symptoms. Heat-labile toxin is associated with bacterial infections such as E. coli, which can cause acute diarrhea but would not explain the prolonged symptoms.
